newsitem.title: USA: Conseco buys insurance firms for more than $1.7 billion.
newsitem.headline: Conseco buys insurance firms for more than $1.7 billion.

text.p: Conseco Inc., the life insurer that has made a string of acquisitions, said Monday it would acquire two insurance companies and buy the rest of two others in deals worth more than $1.7 billion.

The transactions will sharpen Conseco's focus on serving the nation's ageing population and make it a major player in long-term and supplemental health care insurance and universal life insurance, officials and analysts said.

The Carmel, Ind.-based company said it agreed to acquire American Travellers Corp., which provides long-term care insurance, for $793 million in stock, and Capitol American Financial Corp., a provider of cancer insurance and other health coverage, for $650 milion in cash and stock.

It also said it plans to buy the stock of American Life Holdings that it does not already own for $165 million in cash and the rest of Bankers Life Holding Corp. for $117 million. American Life provides guaranteed investment contracts for retirement and Bankers Life provides supplemental health insurance products for senior citizens.
Analyst Seth Potter at Sands Brothers & Co. said the acquisitions "will give Conseco a lot of muscle, especially in long-term care."
Frederick Sandburg at Everen Securities said as those 45 to 60 years old continue ageing, demand for insurance in the markets targeted by Conseco will steadily rise.
"After the transactions are completed, we will have a Number One position in long-term care" insurance, Conseco Chairman Stephen Hilbert told reporters in a teleconference.
The deals will also make it the second biggest in universal life insurance, where the premiums and benefits are adjustable, behind State Farm Insurance, he said.
Investors applauded the announcements and Conseco's stock gained $2 to $44 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Hilbert said Conseco expects to realise savings of about $31 million from the transactions, which are expected to be completed by the fourth quarter.
Savings will come mainly from consolidating data processing, investment management and other financial functions, he said, adding it was too early to gauge the extent of any staff cutbacks.
Some analysts have criticised the company for focusing too much on acquisitions and not enough on its finances.
But Hilbert, noting the industry was consolidating rapidly, said there was a misperception about its growth strategy.

"Dig through the numbers and you'll find 60 percent of our growth has come from how we have taken those companies, created a better product line and broadened their distribution for internal growth," Hilbert said.
"We are going to be looking at future transactions, but we're going to be very selective," he added.

After the transactions are completed, Conseco said it will have $30 billion of assets under management, $26 billion of assets on its balance sheet, $6.8 billion of annual premiums and revenues and more than $650 million of projected annual earnings.
Hilbert said the acquisitions were expected to boost the company's 1997 operating earnings.
American Travellers added $3.19 to $31.56 on Nasdaq market, Bankers Life Holding jumped $2.375 to $24.125 and Capitol American Financial jumped $9.875 to $34.875, both on the NYSE.
American Life was unchanged at $24 on Nasdaq.
